conclusion: Consider the geometry of the loop and the changing magnetic flux as it moves through the magnetic field.
The loop is an equilateral triangle with side length a. Point D is on the left side of the dashed line MN, and point C is on the right side.
When the loop enters the magnetic field, part of it will be inside the field and part outside.
Let x be the distance from point D to point E (where E is the foot of the perpendicular from D to the opposite side CE).
Since triangle CDE is isosceles with CD = CE = a, and angle CDE = 60 degrees, DE = a cos(30 degrees) = a√3/2.
The horizontal distance from D to E is x = DE = a√3/2.
The effective length of the loop inside the magnetic field at any given time t is the length of side CD minus the part that is moving out of the field.
The speed of the loop entering the field is v.
The time taken for the loop to move a distance x is t = x/v = (a√3/2)/v = a√3/2v.
During this time, the part of side CD that is still inside the field is BD = a - x * (t/(a√3/2)) = a.
The induced EMF is given by E = B * l * v, where l is the effective length of the loop inside the magnetic field.
The maximum effective length occurs when the entire side CD is inside the field, which is a.
The maximum induced EMF is E_max = B * a * v = Bav.
